Award.AwardTitle: CONFERENCE: 2017 The Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems Orlando, FL

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ITherm is a leading international conference for scientific and engineering thermal, thermo-mechanical and emerging technologies related with electronic devices, packages, and systems. Recent progress on electronics thermal management has been motivated in part by increase in microprocessor power densities, power semiconductor lasers, and radar amplifiers. As the performance density of high-power electronic systems is severely limited by their cooling systems, their need for sophisticated cooling mechanisms increases concomitantly. The conference targets the electronics thermal management community by organizing five specific technical talks on critical topics including Aerospace Thermal Management, ICE-Cool: Intrachip/Interchip Enhanced Cooling, Advanced Cooling Solutions for Photonics, Embedded Inter/Intra-chip, Cooling, and Microfluidics. Also, there will be six technical panels about Light-emitting diode (LED) Packaging, Thermal Issues for Mobile Devices, Micro-Two-Phase Liquid Cooling Systems, Design Challenges in Internet of Things (IoT), X-ray Characterization of Highly Conductive Materials, and Data Centers and Emerging Technologies. The focused characteristic of the conference is an additional attractive point, especially to young researchers interested in cooling of electronics.


The conference will launch the formation of the Women and Diversity Chapter for ITherm providing an excellent opportunity for an annual gathering that serves to establish invaluable networking opportunities within this niche community. While improving female participation at the ITherm conference is the direct target of the proposal, this effort should lead also to increasing attendance from the Hispanic, African-American, and disabled engineer groups. The requested support will allow undergraduate, graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and young faculty to participate in the conference, with special consideration given to minorities and women.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intersociety Conference on Thermal and Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems (ITherm) conference is designed to advance thermal and thermomechanical issues and discusses the emerging technology issues related with electronic devices, packages, and systems. To advance the scientific impacts, ITherm designed the technical sessions in parallel, panel sessions, and student posters and workshop during the funding period. 

In addition, ITherm was passionate about initiating an effort to advance diversity, equity, and inclusion in the thermal engineering in order to reflect the diversity of academic settings and our community. ITherm thereby proposed new forms of communication by implementing the first Women and Diversity Chapter in 2017. This chapter has invited successful 3-4 leaders with diversity from both academia and industry and arranged discussion session between moderators and panelists followed by social events to promote networking connections within this niche community. The successful implementation of the Women and Diversity Chapter has provided a platform for leaders to serve as role models of young engineers, which might help to increase the attendance with a diverse background for future thermal conferences. During the funding period, the NSF conference grant supported the travel for panelists, young engineers, graduates, and undergraduate students to facilitate the participation in the Women and Diversity Chapter in 2017 and 2018. In ITherm 2018, the organization pursued the similar effort and has improved the Women and Diversity Chapter even further by co-organizing the chapter with ECTC (IEEE Electronic Components and Technology Conference), resulting in a large number of attendees. In this process, the NSF funding encouraged the participation of younger generations with diverse background to share their experiences. ITherm committee considers this event is very important as the suggested improvements in diversity, equity, and inclusion in the thermal engineering community can advance the ways of thinking by widening overall research outcomes related to thermal engineering. After the events, the evaluation forms and detailed statistics were collected and reported.
